comment._content: this is great ... my dad used to box too in the 40s .. and we still have his trophys .that look very much like these, we use one as a sugar pot always have and always will haha .... i will have to ask him if he wore the outfit too . what a great photo

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: From the body language it would appear that it was very cold, the knees locked together in a ladylike fashion.  The standard of Army boxing at that time was very high partly because the numbers were very high, partly due to talent and partly due to the provision of "facilities" where promising boxers were given time and training to help them improve.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Are there still boxing teams in the army?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Those lads look a bit cold alright, I'm sure it was a typical cold damp March day in Waterford. This photo would have been taken in the Infantry Barracks by the way.

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: That's another crackin image Carol, the haircut on left of centre is epic! I'm sure these lads were well able to fight!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: that officer is no daw, he wasn't going to sit around in shorts and singlet!!!!!  Yes there are still boxers in the Army, Michael Carruth the Olympic gold medallist was in the army when he won!
